title: Morning Fitness at Fort Tryon Park
description:
Date: March 14, 2019

Come to Fort Tryon Park and try something new. Join us on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings for one hour of walking, stretching, and strengthening exercises.

For a breath of fresh air, take your workouts outdoors. Parks are becoming a logical alternative environment for those who want to add variety to their workouts, or who just don't like the gym. And, it's an affordable way to increase physical activity opportunities, because there's nothing special to build.

Exercise with a view, in natural sunlight, with green scenery all around bestows health benefits that can’t be found indoors. Scientific studies have shown that the pleasure of being outdoors for example gives your brain, psyche, and immune system an extra boost.

All of our fitness programs are free, led by trained professionals, and suitable for all levels. Wear comfortable clothing and bring water. Please check back for rain and weather/air advisory cancels.

Please note: Fitness programs are canceled if the weather is lower than 20 degrees and when there are icy conditions. Saturday morning walks begin at 8:30 a.m.

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Heather Garden (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Heather Garden (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Fitness

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 14, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

title: Central Park Tour: Iconic Views of Central Park
description:
Date: March 14, 2019

Take our signature tour, and let Central Park Conservancy guides give you an insider's look at some of the most iconic features of the world's greatest urban park. Learn how rocky, swampy land was built into the living work of art that is Central Park today. Highlights of this tour include the Dairy, Sheep Meadow, Cherry Hill, The Lake, Bow Bridge, Bethesda Terrace, The Mall, and Literary Walk.

Audio enhancement equipment will be used for this tour. A limited number of hearing loops are available and can be requested with ticket purchase.

Details

Meet: Dairy Visitor Center & Gift Shop (mid-Park between 64th and 65th Streets). Enter the Park at 60th Street and Fifth Avenue, and follow the path adjacent to the drive (road) north; the Dairy will be on your left. Please note Google Maps does not recognize this location. Map of the start location

Terrain: A few inclines and some stairs.

Length of Tour: Approximately 90 minutes

Cost: Tickets $15 (Members $10). Purchase tickets online!

For weather cancellation and other ticket policies, please review our Tours Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ).

Groups of seven or more must schedule a group tour three weeks in advance at tours@centralparknyc.org.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 11:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 310-6600

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 14, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 227-1463

Location: Conference House Park Visitor Center (in Conference House Park)

title: Food Justice 101 Part 2: A Workshop for Kids and Teens
description:
Date: March 14, 2019

This workshop is designed to arm young people with the tools they need to critically explore the food system and learn how they can be active participants in its transformation.

Throughout New York City, there are many efforts underway to create alternative ways of producing and accessing food, including urban farms, community and school gardens, soup kitchens, and compost facilities. In order to fix our broken food system, a crucial first step is to understand it.

RSVP on Eventbrite.

The first part of this series served as an introduction and we will continue to delve deeper into questions such as: What is the food system? Where does our food come from and how does it get to our plates? Why do some New Yorkers have better access to healthy food options while others do not? You do not need to have attended the first part of this series to attend this one — all youth are welcome and students younger than 21 years old are particularly encouraged to attend.

Please bring a photo ID if you have one, and allow time to get through security.

End time: 7:00 pm

title: Race & Revolution: Reimagining Monuments Exhibit Opening
description:
Date: March 14, 2019

OSH’s new contemporary art exhibit, Race and Revolution: Reimagining Monuments, will open on March 14 at 6:00 p.m. The show questions the relationship between historical memory and historical monuments and what the underlying implications are for those histories that remain absent. Seventeen artists were asked to envision monuments that add depth and truth to New York’s compelling history.

Quotations from historical documents that correspond to exhibiting monuments will be displayed alongside the artists’ work to reveal their relevance.
Artists were selected through an open call. They were invited to draw from a list of contentious monuments, sites, and individuals, but could also suggest a topic that inspired them. Their proposals showed concern for language, prominence, place, transformation, and reconciliation. These imagined monuments are an opportunity for artists to access all of New York City’s complexities and to honor how its challenging past has shaped the city into the diverse, energetic, thriving, creative mega-destination that it is today.

Through drawings, quilts, interactive sculptural pieces, and paintings the artists are more interested in creating inclusive, dimensional histories than in erecting massive symbols with a limited perspective, addressing often debated figures such as Christopher Columbus and George Washington. They also offer insight into how collective thinking has shaped New York's story. What we learn and understand shapes how we remember the past. Curated by Katie Fuller, Reimagining Monuments becomes an incubator for creative responses to these challenging questions.

The exhibit builds on Fuller’s Race and Revolution arts education series which aims to bring the conversation of past racism into the present. The interpretive nature of art allows a viewer to respond in a personal way, while the language of historical documents speaks to the facts. The two-act in dialogue, communicating patterns of systemic racism and white supremacy.

Exhibiting artists include Alexis Callender, Ayasha Guerin, Chip Thomas, Damien Davis, Emmaline Payette, Kamau Ware, Kimberly Becoat, Lyra Monteiro, Maureen Conner, Maureen McNeil, Marilyn Nance, Rose Desiano, Sal Munoz, Studio Darn, Zaq Landsberg and Jennifer Mack Watkins.

Image: "Robes" by DARNstudio
Materials: custom-printed matchbooks, felt, thread

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 9:00 pm

title: Sunrise Tai Chi
description:
Date: March 15, 2019

Tai Chi focuses the mind while training the body — meditation through movement. Once learned, it can be maintained easily as a healthy life-long practice, easily adapted to your abilities and/or limitations. Due to continuous movements, especially shifting body weight from one leg to another, Tai Chi delivers countless benefits, including increased strength, conditioning, balance, coordination, flexibility, stamina, range of motion, bone density, joint lubrication, mind/body connection; and more confidence, peace of mind thru-out the day, improved sleep at night.

Note that this is the oldest original Chen-Style Tai Chi, taught by traditional instruction, where each student learns at their own pace and builds up their knowledge bit-by-bit.

Start time: 8:00 am

End time: 9:00 am

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 15, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 15, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

title: Central Park Tour: Northern Forts
description:
Date: March 15, 2019

Did you know that the north end of Central Park has a rich history that includes the British having been stationed here during the American Revolution, and American troops stationed there during the War of 1812? Recent archaeological and historical investigations in the area have revealed even more information about how the "Fort Landscape" was used in the late 18th and early 19th centuries before this area was part of Central Park. This season, join our guides and learn the history of this part of the park, get insight into the studies in the area, and appreciate the recent restorations undertaken by the Conservancy.

Highlights of this tour include McGowan's Pass, Fort Clinton, Nutter's Battery, and the Harlem Meer.

The tour route involves many hills and stairs, and some uneven terrain. The tour starts at Charles A. Dana Discovery Center (inside the park at 110th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues) and ends near the park perimeter at 106th Street and Fifth Avenue.

Details

Meeting location: Charles A. Dana Discovery Center (inside the Park at 110th Street between Lenox and Fifth Avenues). Tour ends near the Park perimeter at 106th Street and Fifth Avenue. Map of the start location
Terrain: Uneven, with many hills and stairs
Length of Tour: approximately 90 minutes
Cost: Tickets $15 (Members $10), Purchase tickets here!

For weather cancellation and other ticket policies, please review the Central Park Conservancy's policies carefully.

Groups of seven or more must schedule a custom tour three weeks in advance at tours@centralparknyc.org.For more information, please review the Frequently Asked Questions.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 12:30 pm

Contact phone: (212) 860-1370

title: Central Park Tour: Iconic Views of Central Park
description:
Date: March 15, 2019

Take our signature tour, and let Central Park Conservancy guides give you an insider's look at some of the most iconic features of the world's greatest urban park. Learn how rocky, swampy land was built into the living work of art that is Central Park today. Highlights of this tour include the Dairy, Sheep Meadow, Cherry Hill, The Lake, Bow Bridge, Bethesda Terrace, The Mall, and Literary Walk.

Audio enhancement equipment will be used for this tour. A limited number of hearing loops are available and can be requested with ticket purchase.

Details

Meet: Dairy Visitor Center & Gift Shop (mid-Park between 64th and 65th Streets). Enter the Park at 60th Street and Fifth Avenue, and follow the path adjacent to the drive (road) north; the Dairy will be on your left. Please note Google Maps does not recognize this location. Map of the start location

Terrain: A few inclines and some stairs.

Length of Tour: Approximately 90 minutes

Cost: Tickets $15 (Members $10). Purchase tickets online!

For weather cancellation and other ticket policies, please review our Tours Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ).

Groups of seven or more must schedule a group tour three weeks in advance at tours@centralparknyc.org.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 1:30 pm

Contact phone: (212) 310-6600

Location: Dairy Visitor Center & Gift Shop (in Central Park)
location: Dairy Visitor Center & Gift Shop (in Central Park)

title: Morning Fitness at Fort Tryon Park
description:
Date: March 16, 2019

For a breath of fresh air, take your workouts outdoors. Parks are becoming a logical alternative environment for those who want to add variety to their work outs, or who just don't like the gym. And, it's an affordable way to increase physical activity opportunities, because there's nothing special to build.

Come to Fort Tryon Park and try something new. Join us on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings for one hour of walking, stretching, and strengthening exercises.

All of our fitness programs are free, led by trained professionals, and suitable for all levels. Wear comfortable clothing and bring water.

Exercising with a view, in natural sunlight, with green scenery all around bestow health benefits that can’t be found indoors. Scientific studies have shown that the pleasure of being outdoors gives your brain, psyche, and immune system an extra boost.

Please note: Fitness programs are canceled if the weather is lower than 20 degrees and when there are icy conditions. Please check back for rain and weather/air advisory cancels.

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Heather Garden (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Heather Garden (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Fitness

title: NYRR Open Run: Inwood Hill Park
description:
Date: March 16, 2019

Open Run is a community-based, volunteer-led running initiative bringing free weekly runs and walks to local neighborhood parks, across all five boroughs of NYC. All runs are directed by volunteers and are free to all participants. The finish line is open until the last person is done. The courses vary based on the park, but the courses are between 2.5 and 3 miles long.

Participants are encouraged to arrive 15 minutes before the start of the run and to leave their valuables at home – bag check is not provided. No need to do anything before the run, just show up. Open to all ages, experience levels, walkers, strollers, dogs: All are welcome!

This program is in coordination with NYC Parks' Community Parks Initiative.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 10:00 am

Contact phone: (212) 360-3300

Location: Isham Street and Seaman Avenue (in Inwood Hill Park)

title: Tai Chi
description:
Date: March 16, 2019

Tai Chi focuses the mind while training the body — meditation thru movement. Once learned, it can be maintained easily as a healthy life-long practice, easily adapted to your abilities and/or limitations. Due to continuous movements, especially shifting body weight from one leg to another, Tai Chi delivers countless benefits, including increased strength, conditioning, balance, coordination, flexibility, stamina, range of motion, bone density, joint lubrication, mind/body connection; and more confidence, peace of mind thru-out the day, improved sleep at night.

Note that this is the oldest original Chen-Style Tai Chi, taught by traditional instruction, where each student learns at their own pace and builds up their knowledge bit-by-bit.

Start time: 9:00 am

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 16, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

title: Arts, Culture & Fun: Book Reading: Daughters of the Stone
description:
Date: March 16, 2019

Join us as we celebrate Women's History Month with a book reading of Daughters of the Stone by Dahlma Llanos-Figueroa, a Puerto Rican novelist who is published in over 20 anthologies and literary journals across the United States. Ms. Llanos-Figueroa resides in the Bronx and is a regular Comadres participant at the Poe Park Visitor Center.

Daughters of the Stone covers five generations of Afro Latinas from Africa to Puerto Rico to New York City, and is a beautiful saga about mothers and daughters that is simply timeless.

The hardcover edition of Daughters of the Stone was first released in 2009, and listed as the 2010 PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize Finalist. Ten years later, her book still lives in the hearts of readers ages 19 to 70. Her novel is taught in 16 colleges and universities across the United States, and has been highlighted in millennial online channels such as Remezcla and Bustle. Read Pulitzer Prize winner Oscar Hijuelo's review of her book when it was nominated for a PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize.

This event is free and open to the public.
RSVP to daughtersofthestonepp.eventbrite.com.

title: Tai Chi
description:
Date: March 16, 2019

Tai Chi focuses the mind while training the body — meditation through movement. Once learned, it can be maintained easily as a healthy life-long practice, easily adapted to your abilities and/or limitations. Due to continuous movements, especially shifting body weight from one leg to another, Tai Chi delivers countless benefits, including increased strength, conditioning, balance, coordination, flexibility, stamina, range of motion, bone density, joint lubrication, mind/body connection; and more confidence, peace of mind thru-out the day, improved sleep at night.

Note that this is the oldest original Chen-Style Tai Chi, taught by traditional instruction, where each student learns at their own pace and builds up their knowledge bit-by-bit.

description:
Date: March 16, 2019

Central Park has a rich history that includes the British having been stationed here during the American Revolution, and American troops stationed there during the War of 1812. Recent archaeological and historical investigations in the area have revealed even more information about how the "Fort Landscape" was used in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, before this area was part of Central Park.

Join our Urban Park Rangers and learn the history of the park, get insight into the studies in the area, and appreciate the recent restorations undertaken.

title: Tavern Benefit Concert
description:
Date: March 16, 2019

Historic Richmond Town’s Guyon Tavern, located along Richmond Road, has been a cornerstone of the Staten Island community for nearly two hundred years. It’s home to the renowned Tavern Concert Series. In past years, performers and audience members praised the acoustics and the ambiance of the candle-lit building and the cozy wood stove.

This year, an automobile accident left the Guyon Tavern badly damaged. All programming, including the Tavern Concert Series, has been postponed until the necessary $60,000 is raised and repairs made. While the organization is actively pursuing an insurance claim, we are eager to commence the restoration of our beloved building.

To help bring back this community asset, a benefit concert will be held at Historic Richmond Town in the Third County Courthouse featuring the music of Irish Stout and The Wahoo Skiffle Crazies. All tickets sales from this event will enable Historic Richmond Town to make the crucial repairs to the Tavern.

We look forward to restoring the building in time for the 2020 Tavern Concert Series.

Start time: 7:30 pm

End time: 10:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 351-1611

title: NYRR Open Run: Silver Lake Park

Open Run is a community-based, volunteer-led running initiative bringing free weekly runs and walks to local neighborhood parks, across all five boroughs of NYC. All runs are directed by volunteers and are free to all participants. The finish line is open until the last person is done. The courses vary based on the park, but the courses are between 2.5 and 3 miles long.

Participants are encouraged to arrive 15 minutes before the start of the run and to leave their valuables at home – bag check is not provided. No need to do anything before the run, just show up. Open to all ages, experience levels, walkers, strollers, dogs: All are welcome!

This program is in coordination with NYC Parks' Community Parks Initiative.

title: Arthur Vint and Associates
description:
Date: March 17, 2019

Arthur Vint & Associates pays tribute to Ennio Morricone’s iconic “Spaghetti Western” themes, honoring the great Italian Maestro’s 90th birthday. Morricone’s remarkable career has spanned seven decades; he has composed over 500 scores for cinema and television and is inarguably one of the greatest film composers of all time.

Bronx-based drummer Arthur Vint leads the jazz combo, an 8-piece band featuring an eclectic mix of harmonica, violin, and bass clarinet, accompanied by the more traditional jazz instruments of saxophone, guitar, piano, and bass, all led from behind the drums by Vint. Together the band explores Morricone’s themes by opening them up and making them vehicles for improvisation in their disassembled-and-reassembled country-jazz style.

Arthur Vint moved to the New York area from his hometown of Tucson, AZ, in 2007 to pursue a career in music and is now as busy as any freelance musician could hope to be, performing over 250 gigs a year with bands such as Postmodern Jukebox, Vince Giordano & The Nighthawks, Zephaniah OHora, GaDaDu, The Synesthetics, Arthur Vint & Associates, and a good deal more. He lives in Riverdale with his family and is a member and frequent visitor of Wave Hill!

Arthur Vint & Associates:

  • Arthur Vint (drums and arrangements)
  • Ian Stapp (bass)
  • Brad Whitely (piano)
  • Tony Scherr (guitar)
  • Andrew Halchak (bass clarinet)
  • Rich Perry (tenor sax)
  • Blanca Gonzalez (violin)
  • Yvonnick Prene (harmonica)

Start time: 2:00 pm

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 549-3200

Location: Wave Hill House (in Wave Hill)
location: Wave Hill House (in Wave Hill)
categories: Concerts

title: Central Park Tour: Iconic Views of Central Park
description:
Date: March 17, 2019

Take our signature tour, and let Central Park Conservancy guides give you an insider's look at some of the most iconic features of the world's greatest urban park. Learn how rocky, swampy land was built into the living work of art that is Central Park today. Highlights of this tour include the Dairy, Sheep Meadow, Cherry Hill, The Lake, Bow Bridge, Bethesda Terrace, The Mall, and Literary Walk.

Audio enhancement equipment will be used for this tour. A limited number of hearing loops are available and can be requested with ticket purchase.

Details

Meet: Dairy Visitor Center & Gift Shop (mid-Park between 64th and 65th Streets). Enter the Park at 60th Street and Fifth Avenue, and follow the path adjacent to the drive (road) north; the Dairy will be on your left. Please note Google Maps does not recognize this location. Map of the start location

Terrain: A few inclines and some stairs.

Length of Tour: Approximately 90 minutes

Cost: Tickets $15 (Members $10). Purchase tickets online!

For weather cancellation and other ticket policies, please review our Tours Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ).

Groups of seven or more must schedule a group tour three weeks in advance at tours@centralparknyc.org.

Start time: 2:00 pm

End time: 3:30 pm

Contact phone: (212) 310-6600

Location: Dairy Visitor Center & Gift Shop (in Central Park)

title: Sunrise Tai Chi
description:
Date: March 18, 2019

Tai Chi focuses the mind while training the body — meditation through movement. Once learned, it can be maintained easily as a healthy life-long practice, easily adapted to your abilities and/or limitations. Due to continuous movements, especially shifting body weight from one leg to another, Tai Chi delivers countless benefits, including increased strength, conditioning, balance, coordination, flexibility, stamina, range of motion, bone density, joint lubrication, mind/body connection; and more confidence, peace of mind thru-out the day, improved sleep at night.

Note that this is the oldest original Chen-Style Tai Chi, taught by traditional instruction, where each student learns at their own pace and builds up their knowledge bit-by-bit.

Start time: 8:00 am

End time: 9:00 am

Contact phone: (646) 571-5234

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 18, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 18, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 227-1463

title: Morning Fitness at Fort Tryon Park
description:
Date: March 19, 2019

Come to Fort Tryon Park and try something new. Join us on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings for one hour of walking, stretching, and strengthening exercises.

For a breath of fresh air, take your workouts outdoors. Parks are becoming a logical alternative environment for those who want to add variety to their workouts, or who just don't like the gym. And, it's an affordable way to increase physical activity opportunities, because there's nothing special to build.

Exercise with a view, in natural sunlight, with green scenery all around bestows health benefits that can’t be found indoors. Scientific studies have shown that the pleasure of being outdoors for example gives your brain, psyche, and immune system an extra boost.

All of our fitness programs are free, led by trained professionals, and suitable for all levels. Wear comfortable clothing and bring water. Please check back for rain and weather/air advisory cancels.

Please note: Fitness programs are canceled if the weather is lower than 20 degrees and when there are icy conditions. Saturday morning walks begin at 8:30 a.m.

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Heather Garden (in Fort Tryon Park)

categories: Fitness

title: Arts, Culture & Fun: Women's History Month Exhibition
description:

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

location: Poe Park Visitor Center (in Poe Park)
categories: Accessible | Art | History

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 19, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Date: March 19, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 227-1463

title: Arts, Culture & Fun: Make Your Mark: Create Your Own Graphic Novel
description:
Date: March 19, 2019

Join us as we partner with the Art Students League for this series of art workshops where you will learn the foundations of what makes up a graphic novel or comic. We will cover composition, image, and text relationships as well as lighting.

All supplies will be provided. No experience necessary.

Please note: Space is limited so please RSVP to reserve your spot to graphicnovelsp.eventbrite.com. Workshops take place on March 5, 12, 19 and 26 - register for one or all four!

About the Artist: Maurice Buckley is an illustrator, sculptor, storyteller, and educator. He received his B.A. in Fine Arts at Alfred University and has been teaching art all around NYC through organizations such as The Art Students League of New York. He also works from home as a comic book artist while looking to launch a comic book company with his colleagues and mentors.

title: Workshop for Volunteers: Introduction to the 2019 Partnerships Academy Fellowship
description:
Date: March 19, 2019

Partnerships Academy Workshops

Partnerships for Parks (PfP) invites you to join us at one of our many free and open to the public workshops offered year-round! They are a great way to meet, network, and learn the skills needed to get involved with, build, or sustain your park group.

Are you a leader of a community group that supports NYC parks and green spaces? Would you like to get to the next level in membership, fundraising, 501c3 status, or group structure?

We invite you to apply for the Partnerships Academy Fellowship, a program designed to help you take on new challenges, and succeed. At this introductory session, you will learn how the fellowship can support your group and gets tips on how to write a successful application. You will also hear from past fellows and participate in an activity that will help develop your leadership skills.

Now in its seventh year, the Partnerships Academy Fellowship is a FREE program that has helped over 120 community groups achieve their goals. The fellowship runs from April to September 2019. The application deadline is April 11.

Start time: 6:30 pm

End time: 8:30 pm

Contact phone: 212-602-5346

Location: Partnerships for Parks Office
location: Partnerships for Parks Office
categories: Volunteer | Workshops

title: NYRR Open Run: Brooklyn Bridge Park
description:
Date: March 19, 2019

Open Run is a community-based, volunteer-led running initiative bringing free weekly runs and walks to local neighborhood parks, across all five boroughs of NYC. All runs are directed by volunteers and are free to all participants. The finish line is open until the last person is done. The courses vary based on the park, but the courses are between 2.5 and 3 miles long.

Participants are encouraged to arrive 15 minutes before the start of the run and to leave their valuables at home – bag check is not provided. No need to do anything before the run, just show up. Open to all ages, experience levels, walkers, strollers, dogs: All are welcome!

This program is in coordination with NYC Parks' Community Parks Initiative.

Start time: 7:00 pm

End time: 8:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-3300

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 20, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

title: Drawing at the H.H. Biddle House
description:
Date: March 20, 2019

Study drawing fundamentals at the historic H.H. Biddle House in Conference House Park. Perspective, shading, and observing the form are crucial tools to a successful draftsperson. The class will balance the study of traditional drawing techniques as well as learning how to apply these techniques to personal work and in-class studies such as portraiture, still life, and landscapes.

All ability levels are welcome; materials will be provided.

Please note: This is a three-week class. Space is limited; pre-registration is suggested. To register, please email francis.gessner@parks.nyc.gov.

title: Central Park Tour: Stroll to Strawberry Fields (Free - First Day of Spring Celebration)
description:
Date: March 20, 2019

Explore the southwest of Central Park with Central Park Conservancy tour guides, and see it like never before. From a planned military parade ground to the site commemorating a famous activist for peace, one of the most-visited areas of the Park has some secrets to share with even the most seasoned Park-goer!

Highlights of this tour include Maine Monument, the Children’s District, Sheep Meadow, Tavern on the Green, and Strawberry Fields.

Details

Meet: Columbus Circle Information Kiosk at West 59th Street and Central Park West. Map of the start location
Terrain: A few inclines.
Length of Tour: Approximately 90 minutes
Cost: Free; No groups, please. tickets online!

For weather cancellation and other ticket policies, please review our Tours Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ).

Groups of seven or more must schedule a group tour three weeks in advance at tours@centralparknyc.org.

Start time: 2:00 pm

End time: 3:30 pm

Contact phone: (212) 310-6600

title: The Education of a Young Gardener: A Horticultural Lecture by Coralie Thomas
description:
Date: March 20, 2019

This year’s three lectures illuminate how deeply an intimate garden like Wave Hill is embedded in the larger world of horticulture.

Currently, a gardener at Great Dixter House and Garden in the U.K., Thomas was a John Nally Intern and an Assistant Gardener, both at Wave Hill, before receiving a Chanticleer Christopher Lloyd North American Scholarship to study for a year at Great Dixter and Chanticleer. She has come to her career as a gardener after undergraduate work in political science, followed by garden and research internships in the Rocky Mountains and Panama City.

Thomas’ talk will include a conversation with Wave Hill Senior Director of Horticulture Louis Bauer. Wave Hill’s annual horticultural lecture series is held at the New York School of Interior Design.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:30 pm

Contact phone: (718) 549-3200

title: Morning Fitness at Fort Tryon Park
description:
Date: March 21, 2019

Come to Fort Tryon Park and try something new. Join us on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings for one hour of walking, stretching, and strengthening exercises.

For a breath of fresh air, take your workouts outdoors. Parks are becoming a logical alternative environment for those who want to add variety to their workouts, or who just don't like the gym. And, it's an affordable way to increase physical activity opportunities, because there's nothing special to build.

Exercise with a view, in natural sunlight, with green scenery all around bestows health benefits that can’t be found indoors. Scientific studies have shown that the pleasure of being outdoors for example gives your brain, psyche, and immune system an extra boost.

All of our fitness programs are free, led by trained professionals, and suitable for all levels. Wear comfortable clothing and bring water. Please check back for rain and weather/air advisory cancels.

Please note: Fitness programs are canceled if the weather is lower than 20 degrees and when there are icy conditions. Saturday morning walks begin at 8:30 a.m.

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Heather Garden (in Fort Tryon Park)

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 21, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 21, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 227-1463

title: Central Park Tour: Iconic Views of Central Park
description:
Date: March 21, 2019

Take our signature tour, and let Central Park Conservancy guides give you an insider's look at some of the most iconic features of the world's greatest urban park. Learn how rocky, swampy land was built into the living work of art that is Central Park today. Highlights of this tour include the Dairy, Sheep Meadow, Cherry Hill, The Lake, Bow Bridge, Bethesda Terrace, The Mall, and Literary Walk.

Audio enhancement equipment will be used for this tour. A limited number of hearing loops are available and can be requested with ticket purchase.

Details

Meet: Dairy Visitor Center & Gift Shop (mid-Park between 64th and 65th Streets). Enter the Park at 60th Street and Fifth Avenue, and follow the path adjacent to the drive (road) north; the Dairy will be on your left. Please note Google Maps does not recognize this location. Map of the start location

Terrain: A few inclines and some stairs.

Length of Tour: Approximately 90 minutes

Cost: Tickets $15 (Members $10). Purchase tickets online!

For weather cancellation and other ticket policies, please review our Tours Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ).

Groups of seven or more must schedule a group tour three weeks in advance at tours@centralparknyc.org.

Start time: 10:00 am

title: NYRR Open Run: Flushing Meadows Corona Park
description:
Date: March 21, 2019

Open Run is a community-based, volunteer-led running initiative bringing free weekly runs and walks to local neighborhood parks, across all five boroughs of NYC. All runs are directed by volunteers and are free to all participants. The finish line is open until the last person is done.

Participants are encouraged to arrive 15 minutes before the start of the run and to leave their valuables at home – bag check is not provided. No need to do anything before the run, just show up. Open to all ages, experience levels, walkers, strollers, dogs: All are welcome!

This program is in coordination with NYC Parks' Community Parks Initiative.

Start time: 7:00 pm

End time: 8:00 pm

title: Sunrise Tai Chi
description:
Date: March 22, 2019

Tai Chi focuses the mind while training the body — meditation through movement. Once learned, it can be maintained easily as a healthy life-long practice, easily adapted to your abilities and/or limitations. Due to continuous movements, especially shifting body weight from one leg to another, Tai Chi delivers countless benefits, including increased strength, conditioning, balance, coordination, flexibility, stamina, range of motion, bone density, joint lubrication, mind/body connection; and more confidence, peace of mind thru-out the day, improved sleep at night.

Note that this is the oldest original Chen-Style Tai Chi, taught by traditional instruction, where each student learns at their own pace and builds up their knowledge bit-by-bit.

Start time: 8:00 am

End time: 9:00 am

Contact phone: (646) 571-5234

Due to continuous movements, especially shifting body weight from one leg to another, Tai Chi delivers countless benefits, including increased strength, conditioning, balance, coordination, flexibility, stamina, range of motion, bone density, joint lubrication, mind/body connection; and more confidence, peace of mind thru-out the day, improved sleep at night.

Note that this is the oldest original Chen-Style Tai Chi, taught by traditional instruction, where each student learns at their own pace and builds up their knowledge bit-by-bit.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 10:00 am

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 22, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

Start time: 9:00 am

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 22, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

title: Easy Rider - Indoor Cycling
description:
Date: March 22, 2019

Ward off the oncoming winter doldrums with small group indoor cycling!

Did you love riding bikes as a kid? And haven't gotten on one since? Are you intimidated by the idea of a full-on Tour-de-France-style cycling class? Then consider this alternative! A kinder, gentler approach to riding. In no time, you'll go from novice to know-how! We'll build up time on the bike from week to week -- growing your ability, confidence, and comfort! Please commit to at least 3 classes. Everybody rides at their own pace.

The soundtrack for this course draws from movie scores and classical music.

Please note: Space is limited; registration is highly encouraged! Please register by emailing Stephanie.Parello@parks.nyc.gov or by calling (646) 571-5234.

Start time: 10:15 am

End time: 11:00 am

Join NYC Parks for an evening of short films and conversation with these award-winning women filmmakers.

Little Courage directed by Veronica Caicedo
Dramedy, 5 minutes
A six year old decides to take matters into her own hands for the well-being of others.

DETAINED directed by Khushnuda Shukurova
Drama, 9 minutes
Two Syrian siblings are taken into custody at JFK airport as they attempt to reunite with their father in the United States.

First of Many directed by Pamela Guest
Drama, 13 minutes
In 1971 a young actress goes on her first professional audition with surprising and life-changing results

Paris Blues in Harlem directed by Nadhege Ptah
Drama, 14 minutes
SA desperate woman pressures her grandfather to accept a realtor’s briefcase with mounds of cash in exchange for his insolvent Harlem jazz club.

A Hole in the Stomach by Camila Zavala
Comedy, 14 minutes
Living in a world where love has long gone extinct, Bruna is wounded by the sole arrow filled with uncontrollable real passion.

Scratch This directed by Jordan Lauren Miller
Comedy Web Series, 15 minutes
Sisterly love turns sour as Karen, Kaitlin, and Kristen get an unexpected gift from Mom.

Know Before You Go
Seating is limited. You should arrive before 6:30 p.m. to get a seat. Reservations are taken for groups only; please email letitia.guillory@parks.nyc.gov.

Start time: 6:30 pm

End time: 8:30 pm

title: Senior Games Clinics: Basketball
description:
Date: March 23, 2019

Train with us for the NYC Parks Senior Games! At our Senior Games Clinics, you can get a feel for what the Senior Games are like, sharpen your skills, learn new strategies, and meet new friends.

Basketball Clinics
Brownsville Recreation Center is hosting Basketball Clinics from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. on Mondays through Saturdays from February 1 through April 30. Train with some of our best staff to improve your individual and team play for the tournament in May. Instructors will provide the rules, materials, tips, and scrimmage play.

About the NYC Parks Senior Games
NYC Parks is inviting seniors and adults ages 50+ to compete in the fourth annual Senior Games on May 6-10, 2019! Additional competitions include swimming, track and field, bowling, table tennis, pickleball, shuffleboard, cornhole, and a 9.4-mile run. To register, visit our Senior Games page. Registration ends on March 31.

title: Morning Fitness at Fort Tryon Park
description:
Date: March 23, 2019

For a breath of fresh air, take your workouts outdoors. Parks are becoming a logical alternative environment for those who want to add variety to their work outs, or who just don't like the gym. And, it's an affordable way to increase physical activity opportunities, because there's nothing special to build.

Come to Fort Tryon Park and try something new. Join us on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings for one hour of walking, stretching, and strengthening exercises.

All of our fitness programs are free, led by trained professionals, and suitable for all levels. Wear comfortable clothing and bring water.

Exercising with a view, in natural sunlight, with green scenery all around bestow health benefits that can’t be found indoors. Scientific studies have shown that the pleasure of being outdoors gives your brain, psyche, and immune system an extra boost.

Please note: Fitness programs are canceled if the weather is lower than 20 degrees and when there are icy conditions. Please check back for rain and weather/air advisory cancels.

title: NYRR Open Run: Inwood Hill Park
description:
Date: March 23, 2019

Open Run is a community-based, volunteer-led running initiative bringing free weekly runs and walks to local neighborhood parks, across all five boroughs of NYC. All runs are directed by volunteers and are free to all participants. The finish line is open until the last person is done. The courses vary based on the park, but the courses are between 2.5 and 3 miles long.

Participants are encouraged to arrive 15 minutes before the start of the run and to leave their valuables at home – bag check is not provided. No need to do anything before the run, just show up. Open to all ages, experience levels, walkers, strollers, dogs: All are welcome!

This program is in coordination with NYC Parks' Community Parks Initiative.

title: Tai Chi
description:
Date: March 23, 2019

Tai Chi focuses the mind while training the body — meditation thru movement. Once learned, it can be maintained easily as a healthy life-long practice, easily adapted to your abilities and/or limitations. Due to continuous movements, especially shifting body weight from one leg to another, Tai Chi delivers countless benefits, including increased strength, conditioning, balance, coordination, flexibility, stamina, range of motion, bone density, joint lubrication, mind/body connection; and more confidence, peace of mind thru-out the day, improved sleep at night.

Note that this is the oldest original Chen-Style Tai Chi, taught by traditional instruction, where each student learns at their own pace and builds up their knowledge bit-by-bit.

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 23, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

title: The Old Stone House: Witness to War
description:
Date: March 23, 2019

A permanent exhibit exploring the Battle of Brooklyn and the Occupation, 1776-1783

Old Stone House: Witness to War is a self-directed exhibit that takes visitors on a journey through the Revolutionary Era in Brooklyn from 1776 until 1783. Ten themed areas allow visitors to explore this history and consider how war impacted the community, what choices citizens had to make at the time, battle strategies, and what makes these issues relevant in today’s world.

The workshops are for ages 18 years and up.

Please note: Please RSVP to reserve your spot at collagestj.eventbrite.com. The series takes place on March 9, 16, and 23, 2019. Sign up for one or all three!

About the Artist: Jon Bunge has created art in many media including collage, painting, drawing, sculpture, and installation. Originally from St. Louis, Missouri, he has lived in New York City for almost 30 years. He earned a Master of Fine Arts from the City College of New York (CUNY) and also holds a Master of Divinity from Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan.

Tai Chi focuses the mind while training the body — meditation through movement. Once learned, it can be maintained easily as a healthy life-long practice, easily adapted to your abilities and/or limitations. Due to continuous movements, especially shifting body weight from one leg to another, Tai Chi delivers countless benefits, including increased strength, conditioning, balance, coordination, flexibility, stamina, range of motion, bone density, joint lubrication, mind/body connection; and more confidence, peace of mind thru-out the day, improved sleep at night.

Note that this is the oldest original Chen-Style Tai Chi, taught by traditional instruction, where each student learns at their own pace and builds up their knowledge bit-by-bit.

Open Run is a community-based, volunteer-led running initiative bringing free weekly runs and walks to local neighborhood parks, across all five boroughs of NYC. All runs are directed by volunteers and are free to all participants. The finish line is open until the last person is done. The courses vary based on the park, but the courses are between 2.5 and 3 miles long.

Participants are encouraged to arrive 15 minutes before the start of the run and to leave their valuables at home – bag check is not provided. No need to do anything before the run, just show up. Open to all ages, experience levels, walkers, strollers, dogs: All are welcome!

This program is in coordination with NYC Parks' Community Parks Initiative.

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 24, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

A permanent exhibit exploring the Battle of Brooklyn and the Occupation, 1776-1783

Old Stone House: Witness to War is a self-directed exhibit that takes visitors on a journey through the Revolutionary Era in Brooklyn from 1776 until 1783. Ten themed areas allow visitors to explore this history and consider how war impacted the community, what choices citizens had to make at the time, battle strategies, and what makes these issues relevant in today’s world.

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 25, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: Arsenal (in Central Park)

categories: Accessible | Art | Seniors

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 25, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 227-1463

title: Morning Fitness at Fort Tryon Park
description:
Date: March 26, 2019

Come to Fort Tryon Park and try something new. Join us on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings for one hour of walking, stretching, and strengthening exercises.

For a breath of fresh air, take your workouts outdoors. Parks are becoming a logical alternative environment for those who want to add variety to their workouts, or who just don't like the gym. And, it's an affordable way to increase physical activity opportunities, because there's nothing special to build.

Exercise with a view, in natural sunlight, with green scenery all around bestows health benefits that can’t be found indoors. Scientific studies have shown that the pleasure of being outdoors for example gives your brain, psyche, and immune system an extra boost.

All of our fitness programs are free, led by trained professionals, and suitable for all levels. Wear comfortable clothing and bring water. Please check back for rain and weather/air advisory cancels.

Please note: Fitness programs are canceled if the weather is lower than 20 degrees and when there are icy conditions. Saturday morning walks begin at 8:30 a.m.

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Heather Garden (in Fort Tryon Park)

title: Exhibition: Nature in Black and White
description:
Date: March 26, 2019

Artworks depicting themes of nature are often full of color, striving to stay true to and capture the natural world’s kaleidoscope of vibrant hues: lush greenery, clear blue skies, and verdant flowers. In “Nature in Black and White,” six artists take natural subject matter and depict it using reserved tones of black, white, and grey, revealing intricate forms and details through the absence of color. Works in the show range from pencil drawings and oil paint, to cut paper and cast plaster.

Artists included are Tatiana Arocha, Marna Chester, Tom Monsees, Sarah Myers, Amy Ross, and Alexandria Tarver.

The exhibition is on display through May 31. This exhibition is FREE and open to the public. Closed on holidays.

Image: Amy Ross, Luminous Wanderer, 2017, Charcoal on paper, image courtesy of the artist.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

title: Plastics: Pelagic Peril - Extended
description:
Date: March 26, 2019

NOW EXTENDED!

This exhibition focuses on the serious problem of ocean trash that affects the health of people, marine life, and local economies. It also features poignant images of marine life by local artists. The exhibition enumerates specific actions that ordinary people can take to protect and conserve the world’s oceans.

More than 12 million volunteers over three decades with Ocean Conservancy’s International Coastal Cleanup have collected over 220 million pounds of trash, having picked up everything imaginable along the world’s shorelines: cigarette butts, food wrappers, abandoned fishing gear, kitchen appliances, and even automobiles. Trash in the water and on the shore can kill marine animals, injure swimmers and beachgoers, and ensnare boat propellers.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 227-1463

description:

Join us for our Spring Compost Kickoff!

Not sure what to do with all those kitchens scraps? Wondering how to pick up where you left off before you hibernated for the winter? Learn how to convert your yard waste and kitchen scraps into a rich, organic fertilizer in this hands-on workshop. He also works from home as a comic book artist while looking to launch a comic book company with his colleagues and mentors.

title: NYRR Open Run: Brooklyn Bridge Park
description:
Date: March 26, 2019

Open Run is a community-based, volunteer-led running initiative bringing free weekly runs and walks to local neighborhood parks, across all five boroughs of NYC. All runs are directed by volunteers and are free to all participants. The finish line is open until the last person is done. The courses vary based on the park, but the courses are between 2.5 and 3 miles long.

Participants are encouraged to arrive 15 minutes before the start of the run and to leave their valuables at home – bag check is not provided. No need to do anything before the run, just show up. Open to all ages, experience levels, walkers, strollers, dogs: All are welcome!

This program is in coordination with NYC Parks' Community Parks Initiative.

Start time: 7:00 pm

End time: 8:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-3300

Location: Pier 6 (in Brooklyn Bridge Park)
